healthInsuranceDescriptionLong: Health insurance is a critical financial tool designed to cover medical and surgical costs. Depending on the type of health insurance plan, either the insured pays out-of-pocket and is later reimbursed, or the insurer makes payments directly to the provider. Health insurance policies typically cover doctor visits, hospital stays, preventive care, and prescription medications. Some plans may also offer coverage for mental health services, vision, and dental care. Having health insurance is essential as it helps mitigate the high costs associated with healthcare, ensuring individuals and families receive necessary medical care without excessive financial burden.
lifeInsuranceDescriptionLong: Life insurance is a contract between an individual and an insurance company, where the insurer agrees to pay a designated beneficiary a specified amount of money upon the insured person's death. This type of insurance provides financial protection and peace of mind, ensuring that loved ones are financially secure after the insured's death. Life insurance can cover various expenses, including funeral costs, outstanding debts, mortgage repayments, and everyday living expenses. Some policies also offer living benefits, which may be accessible under certain conditions, providing additional financial support during the insured's lifetime.
carInsuranceDescriptionLong: Car insurance is a policy purchased by vehicle owners to minimize costs associated with car accidents or vehicle damage. It covers various incidents such as collisions, theft, vandalism, and damage caused by natural disasters. Car insurance typically includes liability coverage, which pays for damage or injury you cause to others, and may also offer comprehensive and collision coverage for your own vehicle. Additionally, policies may cover medical payments, personal injury protection, and uninsured/underinsured motorist coverage. Having car insurance is essential for financial protection and legal compliance, ensuring drivers can cover unexpected expenses related to their vehicles.
houseInsuranceDescriptionLong: House insurance, also known as homeowners insurance, provides financial protection against damage to your home and personal belongings due to covered events such as fire, theft, vandalism, and natural disasters. It also offers liability coverage if someone is injured on your property or if you cause damage to someone else's property. House insurance policies typically cover the structure of the home, personal property, additional living expenses if you need to temporarily relocate, and liability coverage. Having house insurance is crucial for protecting one of your largest investments and ensuring financial stability in the event of unforeseen events.
lawProtectionDescriptionLong: Legal protection insurance, also known as legal expenses insurance, covers costs associated with legal expenses incurred by the insured in legal disputes. This type of insurance can help cover attorney fees, court costs, and other legal expenses in various situations such as employment disputes, contract issues, personal injury claims, and family matters. Legal protection insurance provides access to legal advice and representation, reducing the financial burden of legal proceedings and ensuring individuals can seek justice and protect their rights without worrying about high costs.
petInsuranceDescriptionLong: Pet insurance helps cover the costs of veterinary care for your pets, ensuring they receive necessary treatment without causing financial strain. This type of insurance typically covers accidents, illnesses, surgeries, and routine care such as vaccinations and preventive treatment. Some policies may also offer coverage for hereditary and congenital conditions, dental care, and alternative therapies. Pet insurance allows pet owners to focus on their pets' health and well-being rather than the costs associated with veterinary visits, providing peace of mind and financial support when their furry friends need it most.

HEALTH.title: Health Insurance
HEALTH.info: The health insurance system in Switzerland stands out compared to systems in other countries. Everyone living in Switzerland is required to independently choose an insurer and regularly pay health insurance premiums. Unlike most European countries and many other nations worldwide, these premiums are not automatically deducted from salaries.
HEALTH.infoList: There are two types of insurance:

basic.title: Basic Insurance
basic.p: The basic health insurance in Switzerland, called 'Grundversicherung,' is mandatory for everyone residing in the country. It must be purchased within 90 days of starting work in Switzerland. It covers essential medical services such as doctor visits, general ward hospital treatments, prescription medications, and emergency assistance. Each individual can choose their insurer from many available companies, which all offer the same services as mandated by law. Basic insurance can be changed annually until the end of November.
basic.p1: Factors influencing the cost of basic insurance:

fran.title: Deductible
fran.p: This is the amount you must cover out of pocket for medical services during the year before the insurer starts covering treatment costs. Note that the lower the deductible, the higher the monthly premium, and vice versa.
fran.p1: The following deductible levels are available:
fran.p4: Once the deductible is reached, you must pay 10% of the remaining costs, but no more than CHF 700. Beyond this limit, the insurer covers all costs.
fran.p7: Once the deductible is reached, you must pay 10% of the remaining costs, but no more than CHF 700. Beyond this limit, the insurer covers all costs.
fran.p8: Example: After a 5-day hospital stay, you receive a bill for CHF 10,000. Assuming your deductible is CHF 300, you must first pay your deductible of CHF 300. Then, 10% of the remaining amount: CHF 10,000 - CHF 300 = CHF 9,700. 10% of CHF 9,700 is CHF 970, but the maximum amount from the remaining 10% is CHF 700. So, CHF 300 + CHF 700 = CHF 1,000 is the total amount you must pay out of pocket.

model.title: Insurance Model
model.p: The insurance model refers to how you use medical services within your health insurance plan. In Switzerland, various models are available that impact the premium cost and the organization of healthcare. For emergencies, vision problems, or annual gynecological exams, the model choice does not matter.
model.p2: Traditional – You can freely choose your primary care doctor and specialists (without a referral from a family doctor). It is the most expensive but offers the greatest flexibility.
model.p3: HMO (Health Maintenance Organization) – Treatment is provided within a network of designated doctors (clinics) and hospitals. Premiums are lower, but the choice of doctors is limited.
model.p4: Telmed – You first contact a call center, which directs you to the appropriate doctor.
model.p5: Family Doctor Model – You always first consult your primary care doctor, who coordinates further treatment. You must select your doctor from a list of available specialists when signing the contract.

add.title: Supplementary Insurance
add.p: This is voluntary health insurance that extends the range of services offered by basic insurance. It allows access to additional benefits, such as:
add.i2: Stays in private hospitals or clinics
add.p2: Choosing supplementary insurance provides greater freedom in selecting doctors, hospitals, and treatment methods, as well as better treatment conditions. Although it involves higher premiums, investing in supplementary insurance ensures fuller health protection and comfort when needed, helping to avoid high costs for medical services not covered by basic insurance.

extra.title: More About Basic Insurance
extra.i1: Basic insurance must cover the cost of medications on a list approved by specialists, prescribed by a doctor. This list, which includes around 2,500 drugs, is continuously updated.
extra.i2: For medical transport not involving a life-threatening emergency, basic insurance covers 50% of the costs, up to CHF 500 per year. Emergency transport and hospital transfers are fully reimbursed.
extra.i3: Basic insurance covers only necessary emergency treatment abroad, up to a maximum of twice the cost of the same treatment in Switzerland. For travel outside the EU/EFTA, supplementary insurance is recommended.
extra.i4: Basic insurance in Switzerland covers dental treatment only in limited cases. Usually, only urgent cases, such as treatment due to accidents (e.g., broken teeth) or oral diseases affecting general health, are reimbursed.
extra.i5: Gynecological exams and cytology are covered every three years or annually if needed (after consultation with the insurer).
extra.i6: Basic health insurance covers prenatal and postnatal services, including:
extra.il1: Seven routine check-ups (including two ultrasounds: one between weeks 11-14 and one between weeks 20-23 of pregnancy). For high-risk pregnancies, additional ultrasounds may be performed as prescribed by a doctor.
extra.il2: Childbirth preparation and perinatal care provided by doctors or midwives, with basic insurance covering CHF 150.
extra.il3: Non-invasive prenatal testing from the 12th week of pregnancy.
extra.il4: Costs of home births or deliveries in a general ward of a hospital in the canton of residence.
extra.il5: Postpartum check-up between weeks 6-10 and up to three lactation consultations.
extra.p7: It is important that pregnancy and childbirth-related services do not involve any out-of-pocket costs or deductibles. For health complications, from the 13th week of pregnancy to 8 weeks postpartum, no additional costs are incurred.
extra.i8: Basic insurance may cover psychological therapy costs under certain conditions. From July 1, 2022, basic insurance includes therapy conducted by qualified psychotherapists if prescribed by a doctor. This means an initial consultation with a doctor is required to receive a referral.
extra.i9: Costs can be reimbursed under standard insurance rules, including deductibles and co-payments (max CHF 700). Private therapies without a doctor's referral are usually not covered by basic insurance and require supplementary health insurance.
extra.i10: The hospital must be on the list approved by the canton. If not, you must cover the difference in treatment costs between hospitals (to avoid these costs, supplementary insurance is needed).
extra.i11: A fee of CHF 15 per day of hospital stay is required (regardless of the type of insurance).
extra.i12: Stays in private or semi-private facilities require supplementary insurance.
